nodes.bodyText: I don't think this is what you want. I found that in the examples I use it you don't know what actual type you really get so if you add the restriction you would need to add a cast the actual value which then fails instead of the assert getting us back to poor error messages.

+ * {@code AssertInstanceOf} is a collection of utility methods that support
+ * asserting that a value is of a expected instance type -
+ * in other words, if it can be assigned to the expected type.

+ */
+class AssertInstanceOf {
+
+	private AssertInstanceOf() {
+		/* no-op */
+	}
+

nodes.bodyText: Yeah, this feels more useful. Actual value is an Object and after we verified it is of type T we can use it as that.

nodes.bodyText: Is it really worth differentiating between exception and "normal" instances here? Couldn't we always say "Unexpected type"?
This should go to the "New Features and Improvements" section of "JUnit Jupiter"

@@ -31,6 +31,9 @@ on GitHub.
   `test(displayName("my test"))` can be used to match against a test whose display name is
   `my test`.
 
+* New `assertInstanceOf` methods as a replacement for `assertTrue(obj instanceof X)` which
+  provide better error messages comparable to those of `assertThrows`.
+
